{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3355413,"name":"Sam Knight","username":"knightscape","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knightscape/{size}/137599_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-08T18:44:16.694Z","cooked":"

I’m looking for a calibration tool for MAXServe modules that has been modified to fit modules kitted out with the Thriftybot billet wheels. The billet wheels are wider than the stock REV wheels so the stock calibration tool doesn’t fit without modification. Has anyone already made up a CAD or STL that works?

Amusing in hindsight: We just added billet wheels to ours right before NEDCMP. We ended up hacking up a calibration tool with a handheld jigsaw at the last minute at NEDCMP to get the thrifty wheels to fit, then had a minor freakout when everything was calibrated 180° off because our hack job had rendered the one-way fit of the normal calibration tool useless. Somehow we managed to flip them all the same wrong way without realizing it. Lessons were learned and we got it all worked out before our first match.

Not exactly what you’re asking for, but this is a modified alignment tool we made. We used TPU 3D-printed wheels which were wider than standard, and two modules on our robot had intake plates against the side which blocked the raised alignment edges. Feel free to make a copy and modify as you wish!

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

We just aligned all the wheels facing forward using a straight edge and set the zeroes, then hand-rotated the ones that should be offset 90deg until the Rev Client showed them as exactly 90deg offset, and re-zeroed at that offset.

Not pretty, but did the job for now without disrupting software and allowing the Rev MaxSwerve UI to work properly. We will change our software next season to remove the 90deg offsets entirely, and won’t worry about the MaxSwerve UI.

We had the 3d printed wheels, and we had a scroll saw to cut the wheel hole a little wider. It still aligns on the fork and edge of the MaxSwerve. It wasn’t too difficult to cut that way.

We stuck the calibration tools in the mill and widened them up a bit without issues.

We have 3d printed and used these to calibrate them with the thrifty wheels, the only thing is you need to find the angle offsets yourself as it is 90 to the rev calibration tool. Printables. I have also designed this which is like the tool linked above, but not clocked 90 degrees off. I haven’t tested the real fit of the tool I designed, so no promises, but it will probably work. Onshape
